It is a theoretical model of the universe that is mathematically sound but hasn't been able to be proven or tested yet. As a Christian, I’ve never had trouble understanding the why of creation or how. God spoke and it was, and it was good. But the more I learn about these new theories, it’s amazing how far we have come. In particular I’m fascinated with light. Light is both a wave and a particle. According to Einstein’s photoelectric experiment, light particles (photons), which have no mass, can collide with an electron and cause a change in the electron’s kinetic energy. Light is also a wave so it can fill an entire dark room with its brilliance, if it were only a particle, it could only hit what is directly in front of it. Lastly, light may be the only thing that could have existed at the beginning of the universe because it has no mass. All other forces of nature, gravity, weak force, strong force, they all fall apart because there is no space in the beginning and there is no mass. Gravity is an attractive force between two objects with mass that are between two points, but if there is no mass or distance, then gravity cannot exist, according to the Big Bang theory.

What I find most striking is the creation account of the Bible mentions that the first thing God created is light. “Let there be light”.

Light is also something God uses to describe his people. “You are the light of the world”. “And let your light shine upon others” “the darkness has not overcome it”.

Another interesting question is why, despite requiring either 10 or 26 dimensions, string theory still has exactly 3 spatial dimensions (and the time dimension in spacetime). After watching the video, I have arrived to several conclusions. Gravity, for instance, may be explained and researched by string theory.
Scientists looked for a more complicated and advanced particle because gravity couldn't be explained initially with science. If the theory that gravity can be explained with string theory is true, the force can finally be attributed to a certain particle which would make it predictable. In some way, this is insane—like straight out of a science fiction movie.
Ok, now explain it like I'm 5

Physics tells us about possible ways of explaining our experience of the world, nothing about the real world. Its explanations are, in fact, approximations. On a different level a different approximation is used. Therefore, it's nonsense to talk about 'truth' in physics.
Every physical model has serious flaws, and they are valid only for a certain range of our experiences that we want to explain with them.
It's important that a theory be relatively simple and elegant if it's to be practically usable.
For an average person the world can be explained without string theory, I guess. And even for a physicist, I feel that it's more like mental gymnastics than a practical proposition.

If we can figure String Theory out,  then we can figure out the Theory of Everything (AKA Quantum Gravity, which is basically just putting together the theories of General Relativity and Quantum Mechanics together), and basically solve all problems that puzzle scientists today. So string theory accounts for 6 dimensions we're not aware of yet. Picture a fish in a pond. If it had the brain to question, it still would have no concept of how life could work for land dwelling or flying creatures because it has no experience of these environments, and no bodily systems to deal with them. It doesn't mean the fish exists outside of their effects, but they experience life so differently from us they're incapable of understanding how those effects work or even that they exist. Gravity feels different in water than in air but that doesn't mean it's not gravity. Because we can experience it both ways we can understand that, but the fish (even if brainy) doesn't have that luxury. It has senses developed for the environment it evolved in. Even organisms that once had fully functional eyes lose that functionality once they start evolving in deep caves because every ability carries a cost and that cost is not worth paying once you don't need that function. It can only peek at it in whatever small ways is has, hypothesize but never prove.

For those of you still confused, here is a 1st grade breakdown of String Theory and what was said in the video. It’s a little lengthy but I guarantee you’ll be able to understand it (I hope)

Once upon a time we thought the smallest, most fundamental thing that makes up everything, was the atom. We now know that you can get smaller (and more fundamental if you will) than that.

It turns out that the atom is made up of 3 particles: Proton, Neutron, and the electron. For awhile, we thought that was as small as you could go. But we now know that the Proton and Neutron are made up of smaller particles called Quarks (we’re pretty sure that the electron is fundamental and nothing makes up the Electron other than energy…

So now we ask ourselves, what is more fundamental than a Quark? What is smaller? In other words, what makes a Quark? Is it another particle that’s even smaller? We don’t know. This is where String Theory comes in.

String Theory suggests that it does get smaller. The tiniest, most fundamental building blocks of matter and the universe are tiny strings. Little filaments of energy that vibrate and dance around (as seen at 5:01). And every fundamental sub atomic particle in the universe was made by these vibrating strings. If a string vibrates this way, then an electron is made. If it vibrates another way, then a Quark is made. If it vibrates in another way, then a neutrino pops out… so on and so on

It also turns out that the math behind String Theory tells us that our Universe has 10 dimensions instead of just the 4 that we know. 9 spatial dimensions and 1 temporal dimension (AKA time). When these strings vibrate, they aren’t just vibrating in our 3 dimensions (up/down, left/right, forward/backward). Instead they are vibrating in 9 different dimensions. I dare not try to explain this further

SIDE NOTE: There seems to be confusion as to whether String Theory suggests that there are 10 or 11 dimensions. It depends on if you are talking about “classic” String Theory or a similar version of String Theory called “M-Theory” One of them typically states 10, the other 11. It also depends on the source you look at. Some sources use those two theories interchangeably. It’s all kinda confusing

To also add one more thing that is very important….

The thing scientists are most interested about concerning String Theory is less of anything I mentioned above but instead something called “Quantum Gravity”

Einstein’s Theory of General Relativity is extremely accurate and has been one of the most useful tools for understanding the universe around us. But it only answers problems for all the large scale things in the universe: Gravity, Black Holes, Time, Light etc…

The other side of the coin is Quantum Mechanics. Which deals with all of the smallest things in the universe: Atoms, subatomic particles, a whole bunch of other behaviors and phenomena at very tiny scales, etc…

Relativity and Quantum Mechanics are the two most accurate and all-encompassing branches of science known to Man. However, they don’t work together. Quantum Mechanics doesn’t work with large scale stuff and Relativity doesn’t work at Quantum levels. So you might think that one of them obviously has to be wrong then. But they aren’t. Again, there is no problem scientists have ever thrown at these two fields that doesn’t get solved, except when you try to marry the two together. Bringing the two together successfully is something called “Quantum Gravity”. If we can figure out Quantum Gravity, that will probably be the biggest discovery ever made in history. At least one of them. It would help us solve everything (loosely speaking). There is nothing more mouth-watering to scientists than Quantum Gravity.

It just so happens that if String Theory is true and we can figure it out, it would solve for this Quantum Gravity problem. That’s mostly why String Theory is so enticing to scientists. More so than the other cool stuff I mentioned a bit earlier. It would win whoever figured it out a lifetime of Nobel Prizes! (I’m being a bit dramatic of course, but you get the idea! lol)

Keep in mind, when ST was first proposed, scientists were watering at the mouth. But even to this day there is no real proof/evidence that these Strings exist. And because of that, ST is kinda becoming a joke. Day by day, ST is taken less seriously than before and a lot of physicists (like Brian Green) essentially get told to move on and forget it (roughly speaking). Other than some fancy mathematics, there hasn’t really been anything to show us that it is real

EDIT: I keep adding on to this. Hopefully this is the last addition. String Theory is also known as “The Theory of Everything” for obvious reasons. Also, earlier I mentioned that Quarks are the smallest particles that we know of. But I kinda made it sound like there was only one type of Quark. Let me clarify and mention that there are 6 types of Quarks that exist in the universe: Up, Down, Top, Bottom, Strange, and Charm Quarks

Protons are made out of two types: 2x Up Quarks and 1x Down Quark

Neutrons are the opposite: 2x Down Quarks and 1x Up Quark

EDIT AGAIN: Earlier I said that the electron is essentially just made up of energy. To clarify, more accurately speaking, it’s a negative electrical charge that exists as a cloud of probability in certain orbitals around the nucleus. Ya it’s kinda confusing. The Bohr model of the electron was that the electron was a point particle that orbited the nucleus in discreet orbital shells. This is the classical simplified model that we’ve all learned in school. Quantum mechanics gave us a more accurate understanding that tells us that model is inaccurate and it instead works the confusing way I explained a few sentences ago. The point is that no one has ever seen an electron and we are pretty sure nothing smaller makes up one

EDIT AGAIN: There’s a few other juicy answers I gave down in the replies when someone asked me a follow up question… if you’re interested

NOTE: If you need clarification on what I meant by….
“However, they don’t work together. Quantum Mechanics doesn’t work with large scale stuff and Relativity doesn’t work at Quantum levels…”

This might seem like a crazy theory, you need to know the other dimensions and how they interact together before things start to get interesting. I'll skip the 3 because everyone with 5 or more brain cells knows what they are, let's focus on how fascinating and possible this could be. This is just my simplified explanation of these, I highly suggest you research this theory with an open mind.

The other dimensions aside from the 3 we know of are as follows.

Time is the 4th dimension

The Probability of other Universes existing is the 5th dimension

All possible Universes branch out from the same starting point. For example if our universe came from the big bang then all other universes were created under the same conditions.This is the 6th dimension.

All possible spectrums of Universes with different start conditions is the 7th dimension. Meaning there's a universe where Gravity repells instead of attracts, a Universe where fire is cold instead of hot, a Universe where Magic is real, a Universe where light speed is faster and a Universe where its slower. Basically every Universe will have different sets of limitations, the Laws of Physics could be completely different in one Universe and a Universe with no rules or restrictions whatsoever.

A plane where all possible Universes have different start conditions is the 8th dimension

Direct movement from one multiverse to another non-adjacent multiverse with different start conditions is the 9th dimension.

Infinite Possibilities is the 10th dimension

Now when I first researched this it sounded completely over the top and far fetched. But if you research all these dimensions in greater detail, the more sense it makes. Every dimension individually might not make sense but all together you do start to wonder.
Having more then 4 dimensions makes more sense Mathematicly,

For example,The odds of winning the lottery 2 times in a row are very low and remote, but not impossible. Its the same concept just on a larger more infinite scale.

Parallel universes is one of the key elements. The CMB or Cosmic Microwave Background was detected and mapped they found an anomaly known as the "cold spot". Located in the "Eridanus" constellation, The temperature of this thing is 2.7 k lower then the rest of the CMB, the most intriguing thing was its size, its about 1.3 billion light years across, and it was originally believed it to be just a massive Supervoid but no evidence has been found to prove this.
It might be from the impact of another Universe colliding with ours. Until a better theory rises to explain this thing, the Parallel universe theory is the best theory to go with at this point.

Another video that takes the existence of particles for granted ("All we know is that they exist!"). How can we know that they exist? In fact, we can't. And quantum mechanics clearly indicates that a non-local field of vibrations is much closer to the nature of reality than the notion of localized particles (the assumption of which makes interpretation complicated or even impossible). Why not assume the quantum field as the (more) fundamental reality and regard the alleged "particles" as local events of energy exchange between such waves (which is the only case where we can really pretend to "see" them)? It does not solve all the problems, buit it makes things a lot easier once we let go of our everyday notion of tangible "things", which is the source of this whole misunderstanding.

I’ve argued since the onset, string theory, or any theory CAN NOT be the theory of everything for one simple reason- as all of the modern theories to encompass all physics and sciences points to multiple dimensional spatial theories as the answer to everything, as the theory is developed within only four dimensions of an 8/9/10 dimensions, the theory could not bare answers to questions we don’t know how to ask. For instance, a life long blind person can understand that sighted can see shapes, that same blind person can’t understand color. They can have the emotions attributed to color described to them, or the physical reactions of color in terms of thermal reaction experienced by wearing a dark shirt and a light shirt in the same temperature under the same sun, but their only means to find that sunlight is in a passive means of seeking the warmth radiating in the similar enough area that the direct photons also interact with. So, creating a theory explaining everything when everything can’t exist within the reality of the theory proves the theory can not be proven nor disprove. Similar to a Fermi paradox, or Schröedinger’s cat idea

The uncertainty principle is often mistakenly interchanged with the so-called observer effect, which is a phenomenon that occurs every time a physical system is observed. The observer effect states that any time a system is observed, its state inevitably changes. For example, when ascertaining the position of an object using our vision, photons have to bounce off the object into our eyes, so its position is not the same as it had been before the observation occurred. This phenomenon, however, has nothing to do with the uncertainty principle, since the uncertainty in the position and the momentum of a quantum object exists all the time, regardless of the presence of an observer. We can basically say that even the object itself does not "know" its own position and momentum simultaneously. Therefore, explaining the uncertainty principle using the observer effect is wrong.

The Quran offers this surprising parable:

Qur'an 70:4 "the angels and the Spirit pass through the heavenly degrees in one day whose duration corresponds to fifty thousand years on Earth".

He introduces here a term of equality between the journey that an earthling could make in 50,000 years and that made by a celestial creature in one day.

We do not know if it is a solar or lunar year. We'll see both cases. Taking the solar year as a reference, we have:

365,25 X 50.000 = 1 / 18.262.500

With the lunar year: 354.36 X 50,000 = 1 / 17,718,500.

The average gives: (18,262,500 + 17,718,500) / 2 = 17,990,250, rounded to 18,000,000,000

This implies that the creatures mentioned move 18 million times faster than a 7th century earthling. The fastest means of transport of that time was the Arab couriers (thoroughbred horses) who reached a speed of about 60 km/h. This gives us a speed for the celestial creatures of:

60 Km/h X 18,000,000,000 = 1,080,000,000,000 Km/h

Back to the kilometer per second, we get:

1,080,000,000,000 / 3600 = 300,000 Km/s

It is indeed the speed of light, that of the illustrious scientist Einstein, discovered 14 centuries later after this Quranic verse and demonstrated. The consequences of such a discovery by the pious and scientific man of the time (7th century) on humanity today is certainly unimaginable. For an incredibly popular video, the definition for Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle is unfortunately completely wrong. Uncertainty principle and observer effect are not the same, please add a note to fix it.

Uncertainty principle is more related to the fact that the broader a wave is, the less sense it makes to speak of it's position (what's the precise location of an ocean wave? There isn't one), but it makes more sense to speak of its wavelength. This is a general property of waves, it has NOTHING to do with observers. You don't change the behaviour of an ocean wave by observing it. 3Blue1Brown made a good video about the more general uncertainty principle.

Gravity is the extended strings that are tied to two objects. The more massive the objects are, the more stretched strings are tied on, so the more gravity (or force) it has! Picture it like this, 0 is object type 1, o is object type two, the - is the string tied to them, and the symbols <, <<, >, and >> represent the direction of gravity being pulled and the amount of force the gravity is using. Here is a representation of different forces of gravity coming from objects with different mass: 0<<=>>0, o<->o, 0<<=>o. If you still don't get it, tie your shoes together with your shoelaces. The shoelaces are attached to your shoes, so they are holding the shoes together. The more available room on the shoes, the more strings you can fit on, and the more strings there are, the harder it is to pull them apart. One more way you could look at this is a rubber band attached to your hands. Your hands are pulled apart, and the rubber band is extended. The rubber band is pulling your hands together, and if you stop trying to keep your hands apart, your hands will come together. The only difference is that the further extended a rubber band is, the harder it pulls. So to fix this, I thought that these "rubber bands" get weaker the more you use them, as if stretching them out. The further an object is from it's parental body (the object that gravity is pulling it towards), the weaker the connection is, and the closer it is, the more strength the string regains! Gravity Solved!!!

M theory, the second superstring revolution, started by Ed Witten in 1995, combines five string theories (E8 x E8 heterotic, SO(32) heterotic, type I superstring, type IIB superstring, and type IIA superstring) with 11-dimensional supergravity. M theory unifies (1) electric-magnetic duality in four dimensions, (2) strange symmetries of supergravity, (3) the dualities of string theory, and (4) gauge theory dynamics in four dimensions.

My problem with string theory is it actually rests on logical contradictions.  A string that is a single, indivisible entity under huge tension cannot then move into other spatial dimensions at every point along it without separating.  The math equations are too hard to solve, and so they break them into non-overlapping regions of space; however, the theory itself says that these extra-dimensional regions of folded spacetime lie all along the string. That makes it untenable to me, unless I am missing something.

Indivisible particles are a funny concept. We can prove that something's made of smaller parts if we find a way to observe them but how can we possibly prove that something isn't?

Also - if we look at matter, an iron bar for example - we'll find out it's actually made of molecules held by forces and lots of space between them. But if we look closer at those molecules, they're made of atoms held by forces and lots of space. Those atoms are made of electrons and atomic nucleus which in turn consists of protons and neutrons held by forces... with lots of space between them again. How do we know, there even IS any "material" object there? Maybe it's all just forces and empty space? The same pattern may repeat infinitely and we have no reason to quess that it stops and where.

The explanation of the uncertainty principle is COMPLETELY WRONG and misleading here. It misleads people to think that the particle moves because we try to see it and turn the light on. It is true but thats not the theory. Even though we don’t try to see it, the location of a particle can be anywhere, so it cannot be predicted. It can be anywhere until it ‘interacts’ with other matter. In the function if we try to locate it its velocity is collapsed, and if we determine its velocity, then the location is collapsed. This is a completely mathematical. Even if there is a way to see things without a light, we cannot predict the exact location and velocity at the same time. This is NOT because there is limitation of seeing things, but that is how it works in our universe.

Some are essentially empty and because we think mass causes gravity, rather than the other way 'round, we posit dark matter. Okay, so, Our universe is three physical dimensions, and one temporal one. At one time, that fourth dimension was a controversial subject. it took a long time to accept that although it wasn't physical, it IS part of our physical universe.
And, to borrow a quote from the video, it generated a lot of beautiful maths.
Now there's string theory, and the mathamatics of string theory works but it has to include six more dimensions.
Issue?
These dimensions are somewhere outside of our physical universe, and being bound to our physical universe we can neither perceive {see] them, nor interact [experiment] with them because all our tools are part of our physical world. All of them except one.
Our mathamatics has always helped us to perceive that which is beyond our basic perceptions, and in most cases, has given us clues as to how we can perceive the imperceptable.
Now our maths are telling us there are dimensions beyond our perception.
the universe is more than what we see.
It's not the first time this has happened.
If indeed there ARE ten dimensions [and that concept is born out by our mathamatical and physical observations of thr four] Then there does have to be some commonality that binds them all together because they are parts of a whole.
Our mathamatics seems to be able to see beyond perception. I THINK [and it's purey my own opinion]that ultimately the ONLY proof or understanding that we will ever have of the structure of the univers will not be any kind of visual model, but a purely mathamatical one.
We just have to concentrate on getting our sums right.
To quote Carl Sagan:
"We are the stuff of the universe, come to consciousness, and struggling to understand it's self".

Heisenberg used the observer effect phenomenon to explain the uncertainty principle, but it is in fact an inherent property of the universe, not just something that happens when particles are examined.

This video misinterprets Heisenberg uncertainty principle. It has nothing to do with an observer sending electromagnetic light to "see" quantum particles thereby altering those particles making their behaviour uncertain. The principle is not even about nature not knowing where the particle is. It is about nature not knowing when and where the particle will create itself. This particle exists for a mere instant then vanishes back into a wave. So, particles don’t move at all. Waves move and particles are momentarily created from them, then release their energy, then vanish, and so on. Motion of matter is an illusion as well as matter itself!

Oh no. Kurzgesagt has made the common mistake of confusing the 'Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle' with the 'Observer Effect'. The fact that attempting to see a particle alters it is NOT the Uncertainty principle. It is the observer effect. The uncertainty principle refers to the inherent uncertainty in a particles position/momentum even if you do NOT interact with it. This comes from the wave-like nature of particles.

Here's my personal theory on the nature of reality, and it gets a bit wierd, so hang on:

Imagine that you are an infinite God: your knowledge doesn't end, and every single possible and impossible multiverse, and the infinitely complex theory of physics behind all if them, is easily perceived by you, as easy as the concepts of on and off. You, a being of ultimate, infinite perception, can understand infinite everythings perfectly. However, as soon as you understand one reality, it's like you finished a video game, you're bored, you move on, creating and learning infinitely more unending realities for infinity, if for no reason than to keep yourself entertained. But eventually, any reality with limits is just as boring as the last, like playing a chess against unending opponents, it's still chess. So, with nothing left to do, you combine all your realities at the edges, fitting them together into one giant quilt of universes, all just barely interacting with each other at the edges.

However, it's still not enough to entertain you forever, and you realize that the only way to keep yourself entertained forever, is with a universe that doesn't end. It HAS no limits, you sow in loopholes to every rule, everything becomes possible in any universe if you know how, which, as an infinite God, you do. You end up designing a reality with no true limits: infinitely large; no matter how fast you move across it, it keeps going. Infinitely tiny; no matter how close you look at it, it keeps going. There's finally an infinite amount of things to do, so even an infinite God is forever entertained, and happy.

Now finally, imagine that, in this infinite, unendingly everything omni-reality of an unending universe, a planet called "Earth" is made. Creatures grow and die, and evolve, etc. Then one day, an odd hairless monkey that walks erect becomes sentient. On a continent later known as Africa, human consciousness appears. And this odd ape is confused; it's species keeps discovering more and more reality, and every time all the answers seem to be there, something screws it up. Edge of the world? It doesn't have one, it's round. Sound barrier? Breakable. Space? Traversable. The atom? Splitable. Now we're trying to figure out how string theory works, and if it does, what are the strings made of? We might someday find the answer, but just like the bored god, there will still be more universe to find, more questions to answer. It is my firm belief that there will NEVER be a concrete, true theory of everything, because "Everything" doesn't end. It was designed that way.

I'm pretty sure your characterization of Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is not correct.

It is not that one cannot know both the position and momentum of a particle because our silly instruments keep changing them - or poking them, as was implied. It's not as though we could just fix our instruments to NOT poke the bird and thus the problem could be solved. It's that our universe goes to some pretty fucking insane lengths to ensure that it is impossible to have access to reliable knowledge of both position AND momentum simultaneously...IN PRINCIPLE. Period. It's less about the observer and their characteristics and more about a fundamental hard-limit on information imposed by the laws of physics; if you have information on one, the universe will bend over backward to deprive you of information on the other.

Kind of an important distinction.

He got the Heisenberg uncertainty principle mistaken for the observer effect. A common fluke and can go unnoticed but the difference between the two is the Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that the more precisely the position of some particle is determined, the less precisely its momentum can be known, and vice versa. This sounds simple because it is. This is just one of its implications but the generic explanation is that it is any of a variety of mathematical inequalities asserting a fundamental limit to the precision with which certain pairs of physical properties of a particle, known as complementary variables or canonically conjugate variables such as position x and momentum p, can be known or, depending on interpretation, to what extent such conjugate properties maintain their approximate meaning. The observer effect in simplest form states that measurements of certain systems cannot be made without affecting the systems, that is, without changing something in a system. As stated in the video to see something is to interact with it, an active process, certain things can be altered by said interaction.

Fifth Principle:
You will understand, too, that all of these transient objects have not been created for the sake of annihilation, in order to appear briefly and then vanish. The purpose for their creation is rather briefly to be assembled in existence and acquire the desired form, so that these may be noted, their images preserved, their meanings known, and their results recorded. This is so that, for example, everlasting spectacles might be wrought for the people of eternity, and that they might serve other purposes in the realm of eternity. You will understand that things have been created for eternity, not for annihilation; and as for apparent annihilation, it has the sense of a completion of duty and a release from service, for every transient thing advances to annihilation with one aspect, but remains eternally with numerous other aspects.
Look, for example, at the flower, a word of God's power; for a short time it smiles and looks at us, and then hides behind the veil of annihilation. It departs just like a word leaving your mouth. But it does so entrusting thousands of its fellows to men's ears. It leaves behind meanings in men's minds as numerous as those minds. The flower, too, expressing its meaning and thus fulfilling its function, goes and departs. But it goes leaving its apparent form in the memory of everything that sees it, its inner essence in every seed. It is as if each memory and seed were a camera to record the adornment of the flower, or a means for its perpetuation. If such be the case with an object at the simplest level of life, it can be readily understood how closely tied to eternity is man, the highest form of life and the possessor of an eternal soul. Again, from the fact that the laws each resembling a spirit according to which large flowering and fruit bearing plants are formed and the representations of their forms are preserved and perpetuated in most regular fashion in tiny seeds throughout tempestuous changes - from this fact it can be easily understood how closely tied and related to eternity is the spirit of man, which possesses an extremely exalted and comprehensive nature, and which although clothed in a body, is a conscious and luminous law issuing from the divine command.
Sixth Principle:
You will also understand that man has not been left to graze at will, with a halter loosely tied around his neck; on the contrary, the forms of all his deeds are recorded and registered, and the results of all his acts are preserved for the day when he shall be called to account.

As may be established empirically, matter is not essential so that existence may be made subject to it, and be dependent on it. Rather, matter subsists through a meaning, and that meaning is life, it is spirit.
Also, as may be established through observation, matter is not the thing served so that everything may be ascribed to it. It is rather the servant; it renders service to the process of the perfection of a truth. And that truth is life. And the fundament of that truth is spirit.
Also, as is self-evident, matter is not dominant so that recourse may be made to it or perfections sought from it. Rather, it is dominated; it looks to the decree of some fundament, it is in motion in the way that that decree dictates. And that fundament is life, it is spirit, it is consciousness.
Also, as is necessary, matter is not the kernel, it is not the fundament, it is not a settled abode so that events and perfections may be affixed to it or constructed on it. Rather, it is a shell prepared to be split, rent, dissolved; it is a husk, it is froth, it is a form.
Consider the following: a creature so minute it can only be seen with a microscope has such acute senses it can hear its friend's voice, and see its sustenance; it has extremely sensitive and sharp senses. This demonstrates that the effects of life increase and the light of the spirit intensifies in proportion to the reducing and refining of matter. It is as though the more matter is refined and the more we become distanced from our material existences, the closer we draw to the world of the spirit, the world of life, and the world of consciousness; and the more intensely the heat of the spirit and the light of life are manifested.
Is it therefore at all possible that there should be this many distillations of life, consciousness, and spirit within this veil of materiality, and that the inner world which is beyond this veil should not be full of conscious beings and beings with spirits? Is it at all possible that the sources of these numberless distillations, flashes, and fruits of meaning, spirit, life and the truth apparent in this material existence in the Manifest World should be ascribed only to matter and the motion of matter, and be explained by it? 2:45 “We just know they exist.” without an explanation, reason, or other evidence, is religion. I’m not criticizing the theory, or saying there isn’t evidence. I’m pointing out what most people pass over as an “unimportant” detail, as a critique of a widespread, severe cultural problem simply exhibited in this moment, anything with the label “science” slapped on it is taken with zealous blind faith by masses who consider themselves wise after listening to it even though in almost everything most people call science these days there are tons of holes filled with faith via the appeal to authority tactic (shamelessly flaunted at 4:45) too many are sssooo susceptible to. Listen to everything, but question everything, and a true skeptic’s radar should go off anytime someone says “just is”, “it’s just a fact”, “it’s undebatable”, etc. Explanations are always owed in teaching. Oversimplifications are better than omissions. I’m not harshly criticizing the makers of this video. Just trying to point out this extremely common pattern to hopefully cause a few people to start thinking a bit more skeptically toward blind faith, regardless of whether it’s used by people calling it religion, politics, science, or anything else. A bunch of people believing the same thing blindly doesn’t make it more true than one person believing it. And the worshippers of anything labeled “science” always overlook the irony of things like 1:05 - 1:15 here. Even when acknowledging that past “knowledge” was false, science-worshippers fail to acknowledge that people can be wrong again. It’s always definitively said that we “can’t divide __ anymore. It’s the smallest thing in existence.” and then it gets divided, and more, and more, but each time people are just as arrogantly sure, “this is the smallest thing now. It’s a fact.” 🤦‍♂️ I know at least 99% of people on this channel will misconstrue what I’m saying and miss my points. Science is great when honest. This seems like a decent video. Just wish blind faith would stop being a constant necessity to complete every “scientific” explanation of anything on the internet and that people would stop totally accepting it with said blind faith without so much as a degree of reservation that maybe that current theories are just as capable of being wrong as all past ones. Wish people’d figure out that no, nobody knows everything and we never will. Keep trying, sure. But stay humble. Hope even 1 person sees my point. Don’t bother trying to start a fight. I’ve said what I needed to. Peace. Nice graphics & narration by the way 👍 well-presented info overall.

This video was somewhat poorly done, because it left out some very fundamental pieces of string theory, which led to an incorrect explanation.

Of the 10 dimensions of space, 9 of them are considered to be sub-dimensions, of the larger one known as "The Bulk." In the bulk, theoretical "branes" exist and on each brain, different types of universes, each with unique physics could exist. It is for this reason, that string theory cannot simply explain our universe. In order for the math in string theory to work, the multiverse would need to exist, thus the showing of more than 3 dimensions of space, which would not explain our universe as the end all, be all of everything.

It appears you want to explain very complex science to non scientists. Don't wish to be negative, but epic fail. Consider this - when you tell a non scientist that you've decided to pretend that a particle is a point in space, they're likely, like me, to reply "well, if it isn't a pojnt in space, wtf is it?" Why do we have to imagine it? It's a reasonable assumption, on the part of the ignorant, that a particle occupies a point in space. I'm well aware this must be wrong, but you've done nothing to explain why that is. You go on to tell me that if you just imagine a string, rather than a point, you get lots of particles, and that includes gravity. You might as well tell me that if I divide my arse by my elbow I get cornflakes. I had no idea gravity was a particle, and I've no clue what you're talking about. Unless you can find a better way than this to explain ideas to ordinary folk there really isn't any point in trying. So many very bright people simply cannot communicate their ideas to anyone who doesn't already understand the science. As so many others have said, no wiser after this vid than before. Trying to make it simple is pointless - too much is left out, with the result that nothing means anything.

For one thing, space is like an old trampoline, it bends, and there can be holes in it. Gravity is just the little divot someone standing on a trampoline makes. gravity isn't a particle, just an effect of them. Black holes and Wormholes are little tears in the trampoline. some of them torn through two bunched up layers in a wormhole, others to the ground in a black hole. Oh, and there are Five dimensions. one temporal, and Four spatial. it goes from point to line to square to cube to whatever we call a 4-d cube, and it can't go any further. It just collapses back into a point, so an unnecessarily hard way to get a point is x to the 5th. It's really complicated, and it took me some 7 years to even get this not very good grip on it, but all the math with the 5 dimensions currently checks out, and You used the trampoline analogy in another video. Actually it was a water bed, but I think the trampoline is easier to explain.

Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is not only a methodological limitation, though. It is fundamental to quantum-sized objects themselves, because such objects have the properties of waves. Your explanation implies that there really are discrete particles with precise locations which we simply cannot see — an idea nearly undermined by 20th century quantum mechanics research.

Also, "maybe it will help us learn" is a true but underwhelming justification for continuing string theory research. Its most important acheivement is unifying quantum mechanics with relativity. If it can be shown that only string theory can unify those theories, then all of the massive troves of evidence for both will suddenly combine as evidence for string theory — very nearly "proving" its truth.

None of the Super Symmetry mathematical formulas can be tested or verified.    String Theory is unfalsifiable and thus is unscientific.  The LHC was supposed to show particles smaller than those in the Standard Model (quarks, electrons, etc.) but has come up empty.  In 2012 the LHC verified the Higgs Boson - a theorized quantum element in the Standard Model.  String Theory is the mathematical foundation of Cosmic Inflation theory and the Multiverse.   And that foundation is crumbling.  Many theoretical physicists are now calling for an end to the extravagant investment in String Theory.  It is time to investigate Loop Quantum Gravity.  If that comes up empty (it also employs String Theory), our observable universe may be the only universe that came into existence 13.8 billion years ago.  If that is the case - who or what created it?

Historically, the uncertainty principle has been confused[5][6] with a related effect in physics, called the observer effect, which notes that measurements of certain systems cannot be made without affecting the systems, that is, without changing something in a system. Heisenberg utilized such an observer effect at the quantum level (see below) as a physical "explanation" of quantum uncertainty.[7] It has since become clearer, however, that the uncertainty principle is inherent in the properties of all wave-like systems,[8] and that it arises in quantum mechanics simply due to the matter wave nature of all quantum objects.

I'll give you the quick answer. Sometimes unusual math is needed to replace parts of math that don't seem to work. Substitutions or more complex math is often used. String theory is one of those things, to get past a math roadblock. It could be true and it might not be. This doesn't say if it's true or not.


To me as an average star gazer who is not up on all the math to really show a proof of why it's wrong, it's simply an attempt to try to explain smaller and smaller realities that puzzle other versions of math, by doing a trick. It's trying to do an "engineering calculation" or an approach which is good enough for the data observed, and this is observed through a whole host of other theories which are accepted. And it tries to go down far enough, even further than what we've observed and add small granular detail to say, "there now that is good enough." It tries to be good enough to solve a problem, but it may lack detailed granularity required to do so. I personally feel it doesn't really solve a problem, but shifts it further down the line. So my opinion is it fails actually and just pushed the nature of a real problem and real sets of problems further down the road. It's kind of like kicking the can down the road so far you can't see it as a problem. But later perhaps you will find the problem is still there.


This involves the tension between trying to know by math what is out there with intuition and math to project math and predict, which often happens with theory, and actually having a limited set of observations (RULE 2 of physics) which confirms it. It's a constant tension between the proposed solution and the observed solution. This happens a lot in physics and is a constant problem. Once it's verified very well and not much can be found to break a theory, then it's accepted. Many in the field of physics think it solved the problem (at least precise enough, as an engineering solution) to work. This would include Hawking whose objections they were trying to overcome.


I personally think that string theory pulled the wool over the eyes of Hawking and he didn't for some reason see it or worry about it. It was precise enough to do the job. But didn't really solve the ultimate problem they were hoping to solve.


One has to realize this stuff is often including a lot of math data that has to be viewed and thought of with hundreds and thousands of scientists over many years. That's to much detail to go into in a short video and videos which show today's solutions may later be revised if a new better theory comes along. The better theories either add to good foundational knowledge or replace them. If they replace them, they are seen as more amazing, because they replace false conceptions. If they add to them they are thought of as an incremental change. (Evolutionary meaning change in a good way here.)

The video doesn’t quite explain why string theory doesn’t work correctly... while the higher dimension problem is a major issue to grapple with, most string theorists now suggest that the 6 (or really 7 if we use m-theory) dimensions are folded into each other. Much like folding a piece of paper can distort a 2D picture on that paper, folding a higher dimensional universe can create and alter the 4D universe we live in. The problem originally came with mathematical anomalies and the implication of a tachyon particle, both of which were later solved by supersymmetry, superstring theory, and m-theory. The major problem with this theory is that the proposed strings are so small we are not even close to a way to experimentally verify the theory. While all the mathematics works out, there’s no way to test to see if these mathematics hold true in the real world.

2:25 No. Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle is a mathematical identity which , given a quantum state |ψ>, limits the possible values of the uncertainties' product of two observables X and Y. Even though the uncertainty of an observable related to a state |ψ> (denoted as <ψ|X|ψ>) is indeed correlated to the "spreadness" of the results while trying to measure X on multiple copies of |ψ>, it is a mathematical quantity which characterizes the state and exists beyond the act of measurement.

This uncertainty is unique to Quantum Mechanics and has no classical interpretation. I know QM is a difficult topic, but please, stop diffusing the false myth that Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle is about "if we measure the position of a particle we have to hit it with a photon so we don't know where it goes".

Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, in the video is not explained accurately. The actual uncertainty is that, if we try to measure the momentum of any elementary particle more accurately, the lesser accuracy in determining its position. And the vice-versa. But the reason is as explained in the video. That when we try to see/feel the elementary particle using higher energy waves, to measure it's mass (or momentum), we tend to disturb it's position like @2:10, but if we try to measure it's position using may be lower energy waves, which doesn't much disturb the position, we fail to see/feel the particle to accurately measure it's momentum/mass bcz the wave just passes over the particle without even feeling it, like @1.52.
In much simpler words, we can measure the momentum/mass of any physical particle only if we can feel it. But these elementary particle are so so so very small, that if we try to feel it (using high frequency waves) we'll just disturb their position. Except for these elementary particles we're pretty much able to measure, at once, the mass and position of any physical object in the universe using Gravity Theory.
Universe is basically explained using SpaceTime and Gravity. Spacetime gives the "Position" and Gravity gives the "Momentum/Mass", which is how we explain whether the Universe is expanding, Stars are moving, Earth is rotating.
In Quantum physics we can't simultaneously apply both SpaceTime and Gravity on elementary particles.

Kinda sums it up. Like the old phrase "the map is not the territory", string theory is just a way to help mathematicians try and make sense of the impossible. It's not the true nature of reality and as the guy said its not even testable and therefore by definition is unscientific. Go figure.

One point which intrigues me: why do theoretical physicists need to have a theory of everything? Why not two? The universe appears to present itself as a duality however you look at it (particle/wave being one example) and this, to me at least, may imply that the underlying essence is fundamentally unknowable in an objective scientific sense. You can see/measure it in one of two different ways and, like an optical illusion, even flip your perspective back and forth between the two but you you just can't see both simultaneously (like uncertainty principle)

I wonder if the same is true of Relativity and the Standard Model. They're not mutually exclusive after all but perhaps they support and engender each other in some essential way. Buggered if I know. It's more philosophy than science at this point but at least the philosophers had a headstart on the problem.

It reminds me of a Taoist story defining yin/yang (ie particle/wave or anything else you care to name) as perceivable aspects arising from a fundamentally unknowable "creative process" - which they just called the Tao and we call the Big Bang/Universe. I don't have a problem with that - the universe is pretty weird and maybe that's the way it works. If so, then could it be possible for physicists to view the Standard Model and Relativity as complementary yin/yang-style models of reality (which work and are testable!) in our 4 dimensions? It's probably as wrong as anything else but at least it negates the fiction of 10,11, 27 or 2 to-the-power-of 500 invented dimensions to satisfy the math. Mind you, it would put Sheldon out of a job.

led to 'inelegant' so-called solutions).

experiences timelessness), perhaps the graviton has been misconstrued, misinterpreted
(?).  Or perhaps constraints were put
upon it that were necessary only due to our limited understanding?

'space-time' need not necessarily end at 45 degrees between x and ct.

Why couldn't these physicists say that these strings are electric vibrations?

From the site Ask a Mathematician, Ask a Physicist:

Q: What are "actual pictures" of atoms actually pictures of?.

Physicist:
Actual pictures of atoms aren’t actually pictures at all.
There are a few good rules of thumb in physics. Among the best is:
light acts like you’d expect on scales well above its wavelength and
acts weird on scales below. In order to take a picture of a thing you
need light to bounce …

The only thing physicists have actually seen is basically a computer
image, not the real image, and second, they observe electric fields,
not the particle itself. They do not observe particles themselves;
they are able to observe only the field. However this alone does not
prove anything, but that the electric energy field exists and that’s
about it---no atoms, no photons, no electrons, no quarks. no nothing.
So no, particles do not exist. Particles exist only inside
mathematical abstractions and nothing more and nothing else. We don’t
know what actually exists in the real world, except that there are
energy fields---electric, magnetic and all other forms and all other
kinds of energy fields.

I forgot to add what exactly is visualized with all these microscopes
including STM--the scanning tunneling microscope. What is visualized is
the charge density of the electric field.
Basically you observe vibrations---electric vibrations.
You haven’t seen an atom either. You’ve seen an image you assume to be
an atom, but it is simply an instrument’s representation of the atom.
It is not the atom itself.

These techniques aren’t actually “visual” like microscopes we work
with in biology classes. Microscopes use lenses and light to help zoom
and focus on small objects. Electron microscopes, on the other hand,
use quantum scattering theory to construct the shape of small objects,
then the data is transferred to a computer to create a model. The
wavelengths of visible light ranges on the order of ~370nm to 750nm.
These are all MUCH larger than many particles of interest (and way too
large to view atoms, which are on the order of Angstroms–0.1nm).
Scientists need to be creative to be able to “see” atoms.

The problem with what we think atoms are is exactly about the shorter
wavelengths--sure shorter wavelengths hit something, but what is it?

So, no, scanning tunneling microscopes and atomic force microscopes
did not prove the existence of atoms.

In the video we introduced Heisenberg's uncertainty principle in terms of the effects of a measurement (what is sometimes called the observer effect). The two concepts are not exactly the same, but the observer effect provides an intuitive physical interpretation of the uncertainty principle---in fact Heisenberg himself used it as a physical justification of his principle. A more precise way to introduce Heisenberg's principle is to see that very small objects, such as elementary particles, behave like waves: a famous experiment in quantum mechanics shows that electrons going past an obstacle "diffract", i.e. they go around the obstacle. This is similar to how sound waves behave: if you sit in theater behind a column, you can still hear the music. The uncertainty principle is then a mathematical consequence of this wave description, or in more mathematical terms of the fact that "quantum observable do not commute". In this sense it is not a principle in itself, but a consequence of the axioms of quantum mechanics; yet, given its historical importance in the development of quantum mechanics and the fact that it is a basic feature of quantum mechanical effects, physicists think of it as a founding principle of quantum physics. It is indeed correct that, while the observer effect gives an intuitive way to justify Heisenberg's principle, nowadays physicists distinguish between the two, and they have been working hard to better understand their subtle differences.

An electromagnetic 'wave' must have a - charge at one end and a + charge at the other. Since it is a wave, the two ends must attract each other. When they meet, the point of contact becomes neutral, or 0, which will attract both - & +. As the charged string draws into itself forming a 'light' neutron, which will continue to collapse into itself (the snake swallowing it's tail) until it reaches a saturation point where further collapse is no longer possible unless fission or fusion takes place on an atomic scale. The strength of this reaction is limited because the instant the reaction takes place, the events that caused it no longer exist, making the reaction 'impossible'. Since the two energies cannot escape their mutually attractive properties the reaction will then occur again in almost the same instant, setting up a 'pulse' between reaction and no reaction. Depending on circumstances and environment, this 'light' neutron may form a hydrogen atom or absorb additional strings forming heavier neutrons.
The video cites the irrefutable math that 2+2=4. This is wrong! If you add 1+ particle to a 1- particle, you get 1 neutral, or 0, particle, so 1+1=1. Of the possibilities that 2+2=4, there is also a possibility that 2+2=1 particle with 2 times the mass of the 1+1=1 particle.

We may never know everything there is, just as we complete the current searched for "theory of everything" we might find another piece that won't fit the puzzle, such as discovering a new elementary type of particle smaller than an elementary particle that tells a story we could never of dreamed of.

In theory, we are stepping closer to "everything", walking towards the end of an infinitesimal long footpath of knowledge,

Using pi (irrational number, not part of the Greek alphabet) as a model:
I (Who only can recite pi as 3.14, I can't remember any more) knows much less and as much as pi as someone who knows 100 significant figures of pi.

Now you might be wondering:
"If we are never going to reach the finish line, why are we still striding for it", its for that feeling of accomplishment that keeps us going, to get a more accurate idea, and to further find a new story, more perspectives, another window we haven't yet looked at the view, and I can tell you with each window the view gets more and more spectacular, and allows us to try new things.

In short:

be part of the team that runs that infinite marathon, find new windows never dreamed of, discover more horizons, what's your theory of "everything". Nothing's the centre of THE universe. But you are the centre of the observable universe, and so am I and so is everyone else in the world, so so is no one but in the observable universe, of which is limited but the horizons are always growing,
Will we sit and wait for more as the horizons expand, or will we dream and think of new horizons to test both what we know and what we won't.

I'm sorry but there are two things fundamentally wrong in this video. First, the Heisenberg uncertainty principle is not the basis of all quantum theories. It is not even one of the axioms of either classical quantum physics, or quantum field theories. Second, in quantum field theories or even classical quantum physics, a particle os never just a point in space(time) - that is the classical mechanical point of view. In classical quantum physics a particle is described by a wavefunction and in quantum field theories a particle is the excitation of one of the fundamental quantum fields.

Inaccuracies:
1. Leptons are not necessarily elementary particles, they just have not shown to be definitely composite or non-composite yet.
2. Observations can be made to 'see' effects without using light directly, such as with clever techniques such as laser interferometry or the proposed 'dark matter radio.'
3. Gravity just appears to act not as a 'force' because of the Principle of Equivalence, on which Einstein's Theory of General Relativity is based. At higher energies this effect almost certainly disappears, general relativity no longer describes spacetime curvature, and gravity is just another force.

the first part of this video is not correct. Although saying that we cannot see fundamental particles is correct, this is NOT THE HEISENBERG UNCERTAINTY PRINCIPLE. The Heisenberg uncertainty principle is saying (in a simple form) that the more you know something like mass (say you know this to an infinite accuracy) the less you will know the momentum of what you are measuring.Isaac Newton had a theory that if you had a snooker table and you could measure the momentum to an absolute extent then you could predict what happened in the past for the ball and the future. If you crashed 2 particles together and you knew the momentum infinitely accurate then you will not know where the particles are. This is really complicated to explain but I'm not saying that the video is bad I'm saying that it is scientifically incorrect. The principle you used is the OBSERVER EFFECT.

Even with the comment in the description I still think you have the Heisenburg uncertainty principle wrong.  The observer effect is what you are talking about, but the uncertainty principle is completely different.  It states that the more certain you are about one thing described by the wave function, the less certain you can be about the other.  An example would be position and momentum.  The more certain you are about one the less you can be about the other.  The same applies to time and energy.  The more mass something has, the less this applies as well, so it is only noticeable in tiny particles.

Tying the uncertainty principle to the observer effect is WAY WRONG dudes.  In your comment pinned I see that you say "the two concepts are not exactly the same," but that's a huge misstatement.  The two concepts are UNRELATED IDEAS.  Even if Heisenberg "used it as a physical justification of his principle," he was wrong.  And the differences aren't "subtle," they're entirely different ideas that have nothing to do with one another.  One is a statement about waves, and the other is a statement about interactions between things whether they're waves or not.

I'm only a few minutes in, and I love it, however the brain does not "create images" nor, as far as we know is there any place in a brain where an image lives or where we live. This is the fallacy of Descartes, the homunculus. The true nature of perception, of representation, of the relationship of that lump of gray between your ears to the world in which there is a "you" that has experiences is something much more complicated and less straightforward. I find it interesting that you begin by asking "what is seeing?", perhaps you can do a follow up video on the nature of experience. You could begin with seeing, move to other sensations and perceptions and do so while addressing the nature of experiencing, the logical consequences to our understanding of our own sensations and perceptions of various theories (e.g. predictive coding accounts, cartesian theatre, panpsychism(s)/panexperentialism(s)). I know you have touched on some things like this before, but not in much detail. It might even be better in German, to "take" something as "true" is of course the basis of the term for perception in German ("wahrnehmen").

I appreciate the fact that you highlighted that an imperfect, but still pretty good, model or explanation is better than an even more imperfect or outdated model, especially if you know where the model stops being applicable and where you should not use it. For example, not flat map is a perfect representation of Earth's geography because it's physically impossible to project a sphere onto a flat plane. But flat maps are perfectly acceptable to use when you are trying to navigate your town, or even most countries; however, it would cause problems if you tried to use a flat map to accurately calculate distances on continental scales because the Earth's curvature then becomes a significant source of errors.

The reason why string theory hasn't yielded any prediction isn't theoretical though, it's purely experimental. The standard model based on point particles works so well that we can't seem to build experiments good enough to find deviations from it in our experiments. We know that eventually there has to be something because the math of the standard model + gravity becomes explicitly inconsistent at high energies (quantized GR is an effective field theory), but everything we can do is still pretty much in the low-energy limit compared to the planck scale which is the natural length scale of string theory.

This video is great but the bit about Heisenberg uncertainty is a bit misleading.  First we do not attempt to measure the speed or position of elementary particles with light, so the reason we can not measure speed and position simultaneously is not due to the fact that a photon will change the velocity of a particle.  Rather it is just a fundamental principle derived from mathematics that the more we narrow down the region of a particles position, the more spread out its probability function for speed becomes, and vice versa.

Dear Kurzgesagt, please stop perpetuating this reductionist, "theory-of-everything", "true-nature-of-reality" take on physics when explaining physics to a popular audience. It's completely ridiculous. Almost a century after the development of quantum mechanics, physicists and chemists are still trying to deal with the quantum many-body problem. Why? Because even if you know the Schrödinger equation for a quantum many-body system (like, you know, for an ordinary, real material), you don't know anything in practice. The equations are too difficult to solve. You need additional insights, you need renormalization group theory, you need numerics and computational physics, you need clever ways to extract the emergent, collective phenomena hiding in the complexity of an enormous amount of interacting particles. Physics is so much more than this "fundamental" story about the really big and the really small. There's a whole lot of length scales in between that are equally interesting!

I feel compelled to state some disagreements I have with this video that I think are awfully misleading

The Heisenberg uncertainty principle is not the basis of quantum mechanics, it is a property along with many other [even equivalent] properties. I think the basis of quantum mechanics is that certain properties of physics are quantized, the rest of quantum physics comes from that notion. Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle is a property derived from certain wave attributes of quantum particles, it is not an axiom upon which the basis of quantum physics is derived

String theory was not a product of the question: “what is more complex than particles?”, and stating such is awfully misleading and even dismissive imo. It is funny, because the romantization of string theory’s origin usually makes me role my eyes, about how some grad student flips through a math book and discovers archaic math... everyone knows the story. Certainly that popular story is overly embellished, but your version is almost callously dismissive

Also, science does not use experiments to “prove” theories, I am bit shocked at a producer known for its great videos, but this statement that string theory has not been proven with any experiment is “not even wrong” it’s completely off mark. String theory has not been falsified by any experiment, in fact string theory cannot even propose an experiment within our current ability to test. This is the biggest criticism i have seen against string theory, the fact that it presents no falsifiable hypothesis leads many to believe it is NOT science at all.

I mean no ill will, and i enjoy your videos immensely, and frankly i was quite surprised to hear these statement from your video. I just felt compelled to reply with my own thoughts

I love the video, it explained things as well as could be hoped for in 8 minutes. I still want to mention to everyone who reads this, though:
There are several things that point towards string theory, or something like it. Those include certain kinds of interaction symmetries, but more importantly, they include the way the maths just works out.
At first, there were several types of string theory, each of which was favoured for different reasons. People were originally sceptical largely because there didn't seem to be a consistent theory. Then M-theory came along, and essentially found that there is a ridiculously huge number of different string theories possible (mathematically), and all the previously established ones were special cases - effectively unifying them.

That's not to say we have a string theory that fits observation yet. It's just important to bear in mind that there are reasons that some of the smartest people in the world spend time researching this.

Aren't you confusing the Observation Effect with Heisenberg? They're not the same, and they quantify different case scenarios. Heisenberg quantifies an inverse scalar of measurement: knowing more about an item's momentum means knowing less about its specific location, and vice-versa. This has nothing to do with observing it, and more to do with how we are able to interpret that observation. The Observation Effect, on the other hand, has almost nothing to do with uncertainty, and everything to do with adding something "extra" to an otherwise closed system.

Let's use an example of a guy, walking down the sidewalk for example:

If you're on the street corner, watching him walk down the sidewalk, you can either "freeze" time with a photo and tell me EXACTLY where he is, at that given/frozen time, or you can measure his speed/momentum at a litany of various locations. But measuring his momentum, in fluid time makes the ability to tell me EXACTLY where he is, at any/all of the given instances he has momentum, nearly impossible... imagine trying to yell out coordinates as he's running by at 5MPH. It's a scalar event, so the closer you are to either momentum or position, the further away you are from the other. This is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle.

Now, let's say that this guy has a GPS speedometer on his wristwatch, and you yell at him to ask him approximately where it says he is and how fast he's moving. He is going to slow down, probably look at you, look at his watch, and tell you that information. The fact that you have interfered with his walk/jog has changed his position, momentum, and overall existence. You have "added something" to the otherwise closed system of a guy walking down a sidewalk... now the system is a guy walking down a sidewalk, interacting with your questions. This is the Observation Effect.

As stated in the video, by "looking" at a subatomic particle by using wavelengths that contain more energy than light, we're adding more energy to the otherwise closed system that is the subatomic particle. So, whereas the particle may have been sitting there, minding its own business, it is now excited that you're asking it to check its GPS wristwatch. The particle cannot be observed in its "natural habitat" without changing that habitat. This has nothing to do with Heisenberg, and everything to do with the Observation Effect.

I think you mixed the Heisenberg Uncertainty principle to the Observer Effect.

Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle:
The more you know about Position X, the less you know about Momentum Y of a particle, and vice versa which is limited by Planck's Constant / 2.
Ox, Op > h/2

Observer Effect:
Measurement of certain systems cannot be made without affecting the system

I saw your reply, they are related but they are fundamentally different. The confusion just comes from "Uncertainty" in the name. I disagree to the use of them interchangeably like this. Because the first one is more inclined to a mathematical and scientific truth while the other is more of an axiom. The Observer Effect happens because of the theoretical limitations of technology while the Uncertainty Principle is more closer to a physical law.

TL:DR, Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle does not directly cause Observer Effect.

It says that we can not directly observe elementary particles because they are so small that it would require photons with much, much higher frequencies. But, those photons would also have so much energy that they would "alter" the particle we were looking at. The solution to this is to figure out how to boost the frequency of light photons without also boosting their energy content. Once that minor obstacle is overcome, Heisenberg's "Uncertainty Principle" will no longer apply.

Particles are "points" in space? No! "Points" are a dimensionless mathematical concept. They don't exist in reality. Particles, being real, have to have a finite volume and, most likely, some stable shape.

In the video we introduced Heisenberg's uncertainty principle in terms of the effects of a measurement (what is sometimes called the observer effect). The two concepts are not exactly the same, but the observer effect provides an intuitive physical interpretation of the uncertainty principle---in fact Heisenberg himself used it as a physical justification of his principle. A more precise way to introduce Heisenberg's principle is to see that very small objects, such as elementary particles, behave like waves: a famous experiment in quantum mechanics shows that electrons going past an obstacle "diffract", i.e. they go around the obstacle. This is similar to how sound waves behave: if you sit in theater behind a column, you can still hear the music. The uncertainty principle is then a mathematical consequence of this wave description, or in more mathematical terms of the fact that "quantum observable do not commute". In this sense it is not a principle in itself, but a consequence of the axioms of quantum mechanics; yet, given its historical importance in the development of quantum mechanics and the fact that it is a basic feature of quantum mechanical effects, physicists think of it as a founding principle of quantum physics. It is indeed correct that, while the observer effect gives an intuitive way to justify Heisenberg's principle, nowadays physicists distinguish between the two, and they have been working hard to better understand their subtle differences.

there is something critically wrong about this video, by an oversimplification. While the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principal can be explained by the interaction with particles, it is not exclusively true, nor is it true in all cases, but the principal itself is true in all cases. the more accurate truth is that the HUP is a description of the Fourier Transform, between measurements of time and space, and that you can only accurately know one or the other as a consequence of math. the youtube channel '3Blue1Brown' did a fantastic 2 videos explaining this in a way that can be intuitively understood, and I highly suggest everyone, including the entire kurzgesagt team, watch them. it's 2 videos. one on the fourier transform, and the other on quantum physics with the fourier transform. The videos are not as entertaining, but they're easily understandable, visual, and very insightful.

You are talking about observer effect, Heisenberg principle is NOT because when we measure we impact it. It is because of particle's wave nature:

"Every particle has a wave associated with it; each particle actually exhibits wavelike behaviour. The particle is most likely to be found in those places where the undulations of the wave are greatest, or most intense. The more intense the undulations of the associated wave become, however, the more ill defined becomes the wavelength, which in turn determines the momentum of the particle. So a strictly localized wave has an indeterminate wavelength; its associated particle, while having a definite position, has no certain velocity. A particle wave having a well-defined wavelength, on the other hand, is spread out; the associated particle, while having a rather precise velocity, may be almost anywhere. A quite accurate measurement of one observable involves a relatively large uncertainty in the measurement of the other."
