One could read, "The Heisenberg Principle" and then ask, "What Is God?"  So many divisive questions, so many divisive answers. When I was 17, having been raised to understand that “You don’t have to be in a building, to believe in God”, I decided that “God is Energy, after all, It’s everywhere”. Now, some five plus decades later, scientists in the field of “Quantum Physics/Mechanics”, with “String Theory”, have postulated that there indeed may be vibrating “Strings” of energy everywhere. Not only in interstellar, but intergalactic space as well. The other half of my postulation rests on the question: “What is thought?”. In it’s purest form, it is merely an inexplicable bit of energy. If that is also true, then that, I believe, coupled with string theory, is the mind of God. How presumptuous is mankind to believe he can truly understand the mind, let alone interpret the will of God. If I may quote the Bard’s Puck: “What fools these mortals be”. Beyond that, you may ask: “Does he believe there is a God?” Yes, I do. Well then, “Does he believe Jesus (of Nazareth) is the Son of God?” Again. Yes, I do, as is every (hu)man a child of God. Well. How then does he explain all the different names of God and ways of worshiping Him? As Tom Sullivan (when he was still broadcasting on the radio from Sacramento) once related, he has an Egyptian friend who noted: “There is only One God, but many different ways of worshiping Him”. “Intelligent Design” came up and how silly it is (for believing in unprovable precepts such as “Gods Hand Created the Heavens and the Earth”, which is based on unprovable, blind Faith). And this from the same crowd who believe (as do I) that the universe was created from a “Cosmic Egg” that came from they know not where, yet just was (but wasn’t for very long), that suddenly went (”Big) Bang!” and voila! We are (eventually) born. No “Leaps of Faith” there. Nope, none at all. Oh yes, their “Resurrection Theology?” “Entropy!” That’s where the energy of the “Big Bang” eventually “runs out of steam”, if you will, and everything collapses back in on itself and, “Guess What?”, it starts all over again - maybe. And they talk about “A Leap of Faith?” indeed. “What Fools We Mortals Be?” “You Betcha!” 
  [The Reply to the "Tolerance-Challenged" Atheists follows]: It is strange to me that so many pass through this mortal coil with blinders on. What is as plain as the nose on my face (and a proud proboscis it is indeed) is that I’m merely trying to point out that because I was raised to believe that “You don’t have to be in a building to believe in God” (even though my middle name comes from the French for Christmas because my parents met singing carols on a Christmas Eve), “The only thing I have against ‘Organized Religion’ is that it’s so ‘Organized’ ” (and you can quote me on that). Because my father had a beautiful baritone and was always in great demand to sing at various congregations, I would sometimes go with him to rehearsals and got to see the good church folk without their “Sunday”, or “Church Face” on. Which means I came to the realization that almost all overtly religious people were all coming from the viewpoint that only their particular interpretations were the “One, True Way” regardless of what those otherwise perfectly good “Church Folk” down the street, and around the corner believed. (Sort o’ like Northern Ireland, or, and more immediately, the “Religion of Peace” vs. the rest of humanity today.) 
  As to the science and cosmology of discovering not only the “how”, but, and to me the equally important of “why” the universe works: In my late adolescence and early teens, I was reading Bertrand Russell and Fred Hoyle amongst several others and was opening a wider view of man’s place in the universe in myself. It was a time when discoveries seemed to be coming at a furious pace: “Big Bang, “No Bang”, “Steady State”, oops, “Big Bang” again, “Entropy”, et cetera … . Then came Sputnik and the Space Race was on. Then came the questions: “What is God?”, followed by, “Where is Heaven?”; then: “How big and how old is the universe and how long will it last?”. To me, it was a logical conclusion to meld the two. Everyone praises Einstein’s genius (especially for his era), yet gloss over his spirituality. Especially in his later years.* It strikes me odd that so many, the “Learned” of our day pooh, pooh the very concept of something greater than themselves. Usually they pause for the briefest of moments, drawing a deep breath of, of something they cannot see (yes, yes, yes, I know it can be felt, measured, etc.), letting out the weariest of sighs, and then proceed to talk down to the rest of we mere mortals, explaining how what they cannot prove nor explain fully and completely is “The One True Way” to look at the universe. 
  We of today look back several centuries and chuckle at the learned fools of the day who were fervently arguing about “How many Angels can dance on the head of a pin?”. Who indeed can predict how the learned of a few centuries hence will view us? In other words, everyone has blinders. It’s up to each individual to open his own eyes and see. Curiosity, after all, is in Man’s Nature. Whether it’s the scientist or the hunter, we all want to know “What’s on the other side”.  We should never stop asking. We should never stop searching. Most importantly, we should realize that we will never find all the answers because there’ll always be another question to answer, another hill to climb and another river to cross. 
 * Well, since I wrote the forgoing, it appears that the "Big Bang" is once again relegated to the trash bin of formerly iron clad "Scientific Consensus". [Or has it been resurrected again? I'm going to start calling it the "Chuckie of the Universe."] 
 ** Sir Fredrick Hoyle’s “Steady State Theory”, by the way, postulated that stars (and, by extension, galaxies) simply “Appeared” to fill the void left between them by a steadily expanding universe. I.e.: “Think of a balloon’s surface with dots on it. As it expands, the distance between the dots grows further and further apart. I believe that new ones simply appear to fill the void between them”; (May I suggest Googling: [BBC Universe - Steady State theory challenged the Big Bang]). 
  By the way: “Intelligent Design" doesn’t challenge the “How” of the universe, just the “Why”. 
   * At the time of writing these words, I was not aware of the exact quotes. Here is an excerpt from a Time Magazine article dated: Thursday, April 05, 2007. Quote: " ... Einstein did, however, retain from his childhood religious phase a profound faith in, and reverence for, the harmony and beauty of what he called the mind of God as it was expressed in the creation of the universe and its laws. Around the time he turned 50, he began to articulate more clearly--in various essays, interviews and letters--his deepening appreciation of his belief in God, although a rather impersonal version of one. One particular evening in 1929, the year he turned 50, captures Einstein's middle-age deistic faith. He and his wife were at a dinner party in Berlin when a guest expressed a belief in astrology. Einstein ridiculed the notion as pure superstition. Another guest stepped in and similarly disparaged religion. Belief in God, he insisted, was likewise a superstition."  
 "At this point the host tried to silence him by invoking the fact that even Einstein harbored religious beliefs. "It isn't possible!" the skeptical guest said, turning to Einstein to ask if he was, in fact, religious. "Yes, you can call it that," Einstein replied calmly. "Try and penetrate with our limited means the secrets of nature and you will find that, behind all the discernible laws and connections, there remains something subtle, intangible and inexplicable. Veneration for this force beyond anything that we can comprehend is my religion. To that extent I am, in fact, religious. ... ."  
  As a dear, but now departed, friend used to say: "Great minds travel in the same rut". (Even yours and mine.)

I prefer the theory of the universe as information processing in an unfathomably complex simulation. I'm no physicist (obviously) but I think as models go, it's the easiest way to unite Newtonian, Einsteinian, and Quantum physics.

Two "particles" in Grand Theft Auto 5 might be separated by a large geographic distance within the simulation / game -- one could be up in Sandy Shores while the other is down in the airport. But this distance is an illusion. The entire concept of space and distance and dimension is just a construct that the machine running the simulation creates, but the machine itself is not bound by having to observe that distance or the travel time between the two points. This appears to be how our world works. We can of course observe the parameters of the simulation -- Newtonian physics -- but as we've learned to delve into the underlying nature of that, we've uncovered some very strange effects that point toward our conception being flawed.

The recent realization of temporal entanglement -- two particles can affect each other across time -- seems to point to the possibility that time, or at least the linear arrow of time that we observe from our perspective, is also a result of information processing, a construct, and does not exist or doesn't behave the same for the machine calculating the information. Again, much like the code and the processor used to construct the world of Grand Theft Auto 5.

Okay, as a physics nerd I have a huge problem with how this video describes the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. I've heard it described poorly before but this takes the cake. It has nothing to do with our inability to measure how elementary particles look. To grossly oversimplify it, quantum superposition says that in the quantum world, things like position and momentum are not constant at any given time. Electrons are in multiple places at once, quarks have several different speeds at the same time, etc. While it's impossible to, for example, determine where an electron will be at a given time, you can model where that electron is most likely to be with a lot of scary looking math. Same goes for momentum. However, as your ability to predict momentum increases, your ability to predict the position decreases and vice versa. This has NOTHING to do with our inability to observe and measure the particles, that's simply how things are in the quantum world. And it can be represented with the equation delta(x) * delta(p) is greater than or equal to planck's constant over 2, where delta x would be the change in position and delta p would be the change in momentum. Variations of the uncertainty principle are also used a lot in quantum field theory. For example, one specific variation says that no quantum field is every truly equal to 0, there's always some activity going on in every field, which helps explain virtual particles. Anyways, back to my point. I said earlier that because things like electrons have to be measured in fields of probability, that's why the model of an atom commonly seen in school textbooks is inaccurate, or rather, incomplete. Electrons don't orbit or follow certain paths, or anything like that. They're better described with the uncertainty principle, and you can only make a guess on where an electron will most likely be at any given time when observed as well as what speed it's going at. And the better you can predict one of those 2 factors, the less you can predict the other. That's what the Heisenberg uncertainty principle is about. It has nothing to do with our inability to measure things, and more about the nature of the quantum world, even tho it's pretty unintuitive to try and wrap your head around the concept. That's quantum mechanics for you. The uncertainty principle is an absolutely huge part of quantum field theory that's poorly understood by most people already, and it doesn't help that such a big channel covered it so poorly and inaccurately. Now even more people are misinformed about honestly one of the coolest concepts in physics

Small nitpick, none of the 4 fundamental interactions are actually forces. Without getting into too much QCD, basically the gluon acts as a carrier for which photons and the electric force are exchanged between quarks, which sort of binds them. But the electric force is not a real force, because it depends on motion, thus an individual quark will not experience a force from an electric field. Instead, it thinks it's being affected by the magnetic force. Hence electromagnetism, and effect made of two phantom forces.
Basically this is what strong interaction uses to bind quarks, and is why only a few quarks can have the mass of a proton even though each one is about 1% of it's mass. Bosons do the same for electroweak interaction but since force carrying particles are so weird, I'll just leave it at that


Also guys, the uncertainty principle was in response to "we can't measure elementary particles precisely", not the consequences of the observer effect. It was indeed correctly used

Scientists, desperate to make string theory work, came up with a surprisingly simple rationalization for the extra six dimensions: Maybe They're Just Tiny. (It sounds better than the infamous Scott Adams chestnut Maybe They're Just Hiding.) But what does that mean?

The classic arcade game Asteroids takes place on a two-dimensional playfield. Your ship can travel up-or-down, -left-or-right, and diagonal combinations of the two. When the ship travels off one edge, it appears on the opposite edge. All four corners can easily be reached from each other. But the positions of these edges and corners are arbitrary. Imagine bending the playfield like a rubber sheet and joining the opposite edges to each other, creating a torus, or donut shape, and you'll see why.

Now, imagine a very thin Asteroids playfield So ridiculously thin that there's no space for anything - it might as well be a line. Turn it into a donut, and it'll be like a very thing hula hoop. Just as the previous donut was a wraparound two-dimensional universe that could only be truly accurately depicted in three dimensions, we now have... the same thing again, except it seems like a wraparound ONE-dimensional universe that can only the accurately depicted in TWO dimensions as a circle. But there is another dimension - it's just very small. Just as a piece of paper only seems two-dimensional but actually has a small amount of thickness in additional to length and width, this imaginary universe has a small extra dimension.

The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle is deeper than 'things change when we measure them'.

Even if, hypotetically, you could probe a miniscule particle with a 'feathertouch' and avoid the measurement uncertainty of your photons knocking things around, there is still uncertainty.

The fact that things get knocked around and are hard to measure because we change them by looking at them, is sort of on top of the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, and is distinct.

(And calling it the basis of quantum physics seems a bit odd to me. It is an important result, but one that we calculate from, well, more basic ideas in quantum physics.)

I strongly recommend a remake of this video (or re-edit) because the way it describes the Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is 100% wrong. It has nothing to do with "too much energy will alter the particle", it's a mathematical concept based on Fourier Transformation which simply says you can't measure both the momentum and exact location of a particle at once. 3Blue1Brown did an amazing explanation over it.

Kurzgesagt is the last person I'd expect to make this kind of amateur mistake, but alas.

In physics, string theory is a theoretical framework in which the point-like particles of particle physics are replaced by one-dimensional objects called strings. It describes how these strings propagate through space and interact with each other. On distance scales larger than the string scale, a string looks just like an ordinary particle, with its mass, charge, and other properties determined by the vibrational state of the string. In string theory, one of the many vibrational states of the string corresponds to the graviton, a quantum mechanical particle that carries gravitational force. Thus string theory is a theory of quantum gravity. (Wikipedia)

Truth be told when a photon does change the observation is not the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, but the observer effect. The uncertainty principle is not only relegated to the quantum world, but to the whole wave world, even macroscopic. As an example it happens even on radars too: to get the speed of the object you are tracking you need to send a longer radio signal, and the signal that bounces is longer too giving you a wider margin of position.

You are completely wrong about Heisenberg uncertainty principle. It's not the measurement, that makes a quantum particle uncertain, it is its inherent property hidden in the math of Fourier transform. Position an momentum of a particle are fundamentally random, and if you try to reduce the variance of the one, you increase the variance of the other. Measurement disturbs the particle, but it is not the Heisenberg uncertainty principle.

The uncertainty principle is not just about not being able to measure something without interacting with it. It's more like the universe itself is uncertain about location/ impulse of particles.
That is important, because there is no way around the uncertainty. When it was only about measuring, we could find a new fancy way to measure things, and then things would not be uncertain anymore.

Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle is NOT about how observing a system changes it!! (thats the Observer Effect) it is about the inherent wave-nature of all things quantum, and how certain properties are not precisely defined, or have inherent tradeoffs in how sharply they exist, when they exist as waves. 3blue1brown just released a very good and thorough video introducing these concepts, check it out!

So, in quantum theories its not that we cant precisely measure some property, but that the position of some particles, distances between them, or in the case of gravity the shape of space, lack an inherently sharp definition at all! ontologically! because these notions are only emergent properties of things that are fundamentally wave-like in some very abstract senses

What you described is not the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle - it's the observer effect. The uncertainty principle is much more fundamental. It's basically the statement that waves are spread out in space, so they don't have a definite position, and conversely, that you need many waves of different frequencies to create something which has a definite position, so something with a definite position doesn't have a definite frequency.
It's just that in quantum mechanics, frequency and momentum are inextricably linked, so you can say that something with a definite momentum simply doesn't have a definite position, and something with a definite position simply doesn't have a definite momentum. And those things are true regardless of whether the object in question is being observed or not.

The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle is NOT the same as the observer effect. I love Kurzgesagt but just do a simple Google search. It specifically states that in the first 3 paragraphs on its Wikipedia page.

Oh dear... Heisenberg's Uncertainty doesn't actually have anything to do with the fact that we affect things by observing them. It's an inherent feature of the universe. No, Kurzgesagt. That is not the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. That is the Observation Problem. The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle is a fundamental statement about the way waves behave (along with some quantum interpretations of things such as momentum). It has nothing to do with the difficulties in observing particles.

Heisenberg isn't so much about the "observer effect" (the act of measuring changes the system you're measuring) as it is about how the mathematics of quantum mechanics reveal that uncertainty is literally built in to the way certain sets of quantum states (say, position and velocity) are manifested.  Even if you could find a means to strike a fundamental particle with a lower-energy particle of some kind to make a measurement about the fundamental particle, you can never overcome Heisenberg.

Your description of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle is misleading. While it is true that measurement disturbs the state of the particle, this is a separate concept. The HUP is more fundamental, and tells us that even if there did exist some idealized measurement process that didn't disturb the state of the measured system, there would still be a lower bound on uncertainties of non-commuting observables like position and momentum. They simply cannot be simultaneously well defined.

Out of curiosity, why are people believing the geometrical dimensions to be applied to reality, trying to come up with some other random measurement and make that a "dimension"? I'd say I blame the word choice of "dimension" for this, but there is only space, energy, and force. When you add time as a "fourth dimension", you break anything that includes it. Because while time has a universal measurable unit system, it's only possible to be used either to calculate speed or decide what to do, in preparations for something or if it's worth trying out. When you add measurements to something, that thing doesn't become more than it is and the increments aren't naturally attached. In other words, maybe it's time to restart from nothing and start to try and figure everything out again, but without the "dimensions" system we accidentally picked up. And, if it can be done, maybe rename the mathematical property of 2d-3d something other than "dimension". Way too many are still being confused by this.

How can there even be a scientific theory of everything? In science, when you test the theory, there need to be conditions that may appear which show that the theory is wrong. If a theory is a theory of everything, then how could there be any conditions where the test showed the theory was wrong? All of those conditions would, by definition, need to be included in the theory, or it wasn't a theory of everything in the first place.

The problem with a theory of everything isn't just a problem of semantics. Knowledge, by its very nature, is completely arbitrary. You can always keep asking question about what you discover, and those answers lead to more and more questions being asked.

The uncertainty principle has nothing to do with measurement or the interactions between particles. It is an artifact of the Fourier Transform used to relate correlated properties (momentum and position, energy and time).  It is a mathematical consequence that appears in non-quantum fields that use the same math.

Wow, the art style is incredible in this video. It's actually shocking how well done many of the visualizations are. Well done Kurzgesagt artists!

Despite this, the inaccuracy and oversimplification of the underlying physics is a bit frustrating (one example, as pointed out by many comments, is how horribly misrepresented the uncertainty principle is). Spreading misinformation under the guise of "making it understandable by the layman" does not hint at the profound nature of QFT, GR, or string theory. While many of these ideas are challenging to discuss in the time frame of a video, concepts such as compactification of dimensions would be very easy to show (especially considering the artist's talents) and would explain more as to why string theory needs extra dimensions. In such an example, Kurzgesagt instead implies that the extra dimensions are just extra problems we need to make away with in the future. This is blatantly incorrect and almost insulting to what many scientists have dedicated their lives to. I recognize I am overly critical, but comments such as "seeing is touching" are amazing and allow the viewer to really consider what an act of observing is and think very deeply on the incredible nature of our reality (I imagined touching with light rays rather than with my hands or sound, which is kind of beautiful). Therefore, any incorrect statements have the potential to mislead daydreamers into wrong assumptions that will be difficult for them to break in the future. When introducing someone to a new concept, extreme care should be used since any biases a viewer develops from that initial learning will propagate to future understandings of the work.

"What is more complex than a point? A line." This is a great example of what I am against, here a child might think they are beyond string theory if they imply, hey, I know things more complex than a line. My solution would be to explain very briefly why point particles break down and why we need strings, rather than just saying oh yeah that's a cooler way to represent things. Physics is a hard science, we dismantle why models don't work. This analytical technique is why we have gotten so far so fast.

While I will continue actively supporting this channel and its wonderful work, I just wish more care is used in future videos on representing such abstract but heavily studied phenomena.

In physics, string theory is a theoretical framework in which the point-like particles of particle physics are replaced by one-dimensional objects called strings. It describes how these strings propagate through space and interact with each other. On distance scales larger than the string scale, a string looks just like an ordinary particle, with its mass, charge, and other properties determined by the vibrational state of the string. In string theory, one of the many vibrational states of the string corresponds to the graviton, a quantum mechanical particle that carries gravitational force. Thus string theory is a theory of quantum gravity.

String theory is a broad and varied subject that attempts to address a number of deep questions of fundamental physics. String theory has been applied to a variety of problems in black hole physics, early universe cosmology, nuclear physics, and condensed matter physics, and it has stimulated a number of major developments in pure mathematics. Because string theory potentially provides a unified description of gravity and particle physics, it is a candidate for a theory of everything, a self-contained mathematical model that describes all fundamental forces and forms of matter. Despite much work on these problems, it is not known to what extent string theory describes the real world or how much freedom the theory allows in the choice of its details.

You've missunderstood the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. HUP has nothing to do with the act measuring, but rather the way waves behave in a fundamental fashion.
To measure a waves momentum you need to know it's wavelength, for it to have a wavelength it must be spread over evenly through an area of space.
To measure a waves position it must be in the form of a wavepacket that cannot be spread across space and have a wavelength.
That's why you can't measure a quantum particles position AND momentum, they are waves.

If a theory cannot make testable hypotheses, it isn't a theory at all. It's just conjecture. If the math works out but you can't find a way to translate that math into experiments, then either your assumptions are wrong or the theory is entirely self-referential and, therefore, useless. For now, at least. "But it's so elegant!" isn't a determination of scientific value, but of mere aesthetics. Surely science is supposed to be about more than whether a given theory looks pretty.

By all means, we should keep working on String Theory, but I find it concerning when scientists treat something as a scientific theory that doesn't fit the definition of a scientific theory. We might as well insist that the "Theory" of Intelligent Design be taught alongside Evolution in Biology classes. After all, Intelligent Design makes just as many experimentally verifiable claims as String Theory does at the moment.

There's a little mistake about Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle (which I'll reference as HUP). It's implied that it arises as a consequence of how we make our measurements (by interacting with said stuff). While it's true to a certain extent that an observation will always have an uncertainty attached to it and making an observation will change the state of the system, the HUP goes to a deeper level. The HUP states that there are certain observations/measurements that are incompatible with one another, and making one of them interferes with the uncertainty of the other.

The easiest and most taught example is the measurement of the position and momentum of a particle. The HUP allows you to make a super-precise measurement of the position, however, if you do so you'll inevitably lose much precision in the momentum. This is not related to how me make measurements, but it's a fundamental property of the universe: because of the wave-like behavior of particles, there will always be an uncertainty relation, regardless of how advanced our means of measurement are (a very good explanation is provided by Three Blue One Brown's Fourier Transform episodes).

I know it's a bit nit-picking, but it's the subtlety of the HUP that makes it fascinating. =)
And by the way: the effect shown in the video is called the "observer effect", and it already happens in classical physics, so it's not a quantum-only effect.

There seems to be an assumption that we "know" that particles exists because we can measure their influence, yet our mind does not seem to comprehend the possibility that there might not be a need of any object whatsoever for the influence to exist. Furthermore it is never questioned what an object itself is, which by definition is merely an conceptual collection of properties that our mind generates. This should indicate to us that our interpretation of the nature of reality might be deeply flawed, it is Naive Realism. We attribute properties of mind to the properties of reality. We assume that objects exists because objects are a part of how our mind generates subjective reality.
We also rarely consider the deeply contradicting concept of reality itself. The concept of reality, by it's nature, points to something beyond conceptualization, but it does not recognize that itself is nothing but a concept. Reality, just like any other idea, is a conceptualization. It is a fundamental notion that governs our mind and it functions, yet it is very rarely questioned by the subject itself. In other words, the subject generates his entire subjective reality, including all concepts of "objective" reality, without noticing that the notion of objectivity by itself is completely subjectively generated. Without the subject, our idea of reality would not exist, that means that objects would not exist. The mind does not recognize that because it attributes properties like truth to certain concepts within the mind structure.
The mind is not only a problem solving machine, it is also a problem creating machine. This is very important to recognize, because the mind is not investigating the true nature of reality at any point, what it really is doing is investigating the true nature of it's own creation, but it is never, or only very rarely, investigating the nature of itself.
To investigate the nature of reality, the mind must investigate the nature of itself, because the mind generates all of subjective reality, including the notion of objective reality. Thus, we cannot derive the true nature of reality from any notions of objective reality, we can only investigate subjective reality. The investigation itself is subjective, because without subject there could be no investigation. Objects are equally subjective because without the subject the objects would not exist, simply because all notions of objects are created by subjects.
From the subjects point of view there is nothing but it's own subjective reality, all of reality is the subjects reality, reality itself is subjective, whatever is beyond the subjective is beyond the subjective, there is no notion, no anything, that could describe reality in any way, not because the description is flawed, but because description is not reality. Reality is no concept, thus no concept can ever describe it. Concepts seem to merely be able to describe motion, nothing beyond that. Math is nothing but the description of motion, so is physics, chemistry, biology and all other science. The mind cannot grasp anything beyond that, and it creates the deeply flawed notion that there is nothing beyond it, when itself is clearly everything but notion.

Further investigation of this matter will conclude that consciousness is the nature of reality, and that consciousness is nothing but the potential of all possibilities. It is nothingness, and nothingness is the potential of absolutely everything. That is how far concepts can get us to the nature of reality, and it is not even remotely close to what there truly is.

Just one thing that bothered me:
Heisenberg's uncertainty principle isn't about measurement problem. It's about the particles' wave and probabilistic nature. It's not that our interference with the system doesn't let us know everything about it, it's that not everything in the system can be defined simultaneously. In theory, even God could not say with absolute certainty both a particle's position and momentum.

Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is DIFFERENT from the observer effect. Our observations being too violent and disrupting what we are trying to observe(mentioned in this video) is an actual thing, but it is NOT the uncertainty principle, which has to do with how possibilities of quantum states collapse when interacting with the outside world.

Heisenberg's uncertainty principle is NOT the basics of quantum mechanics either. Theoretically it is a natural result of how quantum mechanics is formulated mathematically using linear vector spaces as the state space, using non-commutating self adjoint operators in that space as observables, and requiring possibilities of quantum states to collapse when measured. Heisenberg's uncertainty principle can be DERIVED from the fundamental postulates of quantum mechanics. It is most certainly not fundamental.
